pull.title: test: Set assert_debug_log timeout to 0
pull.body:
The `assert_debug_log` helper is meant to be a context manager. However, it has a  default timeout of 2 seconds, and can act as a silent polling/wait/sync function. This is confusing and brittle, and leads to intermittent bugs such as https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34571.

Fix all issues, by setting the default timeout to zero. Then adjust all call sites to either use this correctly like a context manager, or adjust them explicitly to specify a timeout, to document that this is a polling sync function.

events.body: The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers. ### Reviews See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process. | Type | Reviewers | | ---- | --------- | | ACK | [hodlinator](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34581#pullrequestreview-3816303918), [brunoerg](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34581#pullrequestreview-3821028840) | | Stale ACK | [rkrux](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34581#pullrequestreview-3814010446) | If your review is incorrectly listed, please copy-paste <!--meta-tag:bot-skip--> into the comment that the bot should ignore. ### Conflicts Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones: * [#34533](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34533) (wallet: resubmit transactions with private broadcast if enabled by vasild) * [#34359](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34359) (test: add test for rebroadcast of transaction received via p2p by mzumsande) If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

ACK fabaf466b938f0b2da6e25af2eb24f4731fcd358

Agree it's more robust to default to 0 timeout and push code blocks towards being sufficient to print the log messages.

Double-checked that the `timeout` value is multiplied by `timeout_factor` internally.

Ran this 3 times without any skipped tests or failures:
```
./build/test/functional/test_runner.py --loglevel=debug feature_anchors.py feature_config_args.py p2p_compactblocks.py p2p_dns_seeds.py p2p_headers_sync_with_minchainwork.py p2p_initial_headers_sync.py p2p_mutated_blocks.py p2p_sendtxrcncl.py p2p_timeouts.py p2p_v2_transport.py rpc_net.py wallet_resendwallettransactions.py
```

tree d0d9b2a2b88f202904ea1d6c35aeea8523fb9920
parent 07b924775e4ff5dbfb9f2e7549fd13db8ec5c61b
author MarcoFalke <*~=`'#}+{/-|&$^_@721217.xyz> 1770921325 +0100
committer MarcoFalke <*~=`'#}+{/-|&$^_@721217.xyz> 1771341047 +0100

test: Set assert_debug_log timeout to 0

events.body:
re-ACK fa4cb96bdec21319cc54c6dd96a14acf1719e3c6

Change since previous review (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34581#pullrequestreview-3807295159):
Since peerinfo is updated before the debug log (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34581#discussion_r2817331019) we now ping after sending the addr-message to our peer and then wait until we've received a pong back (instead of waiting for addr data), by the time we get the pong, it should increase the likelihood that our peer has logged that they received the addr. N.B. I do not know the guarantees around flushing of the log & observing it on the Python side vs getpeerinfo, but the change makes sense directionally.

ACK fa4cb96bdec21319cc54c6dd96a14acf1719e3c6 

Lgtm, removing the default timeout makes it better to read and understand. Tests should adjust it accordingly. Also, this PR moves some `wait_for_disconnect` to the block which makes sense since it's part of the expected execution and makes the assert_debug_log "safer".

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,7 +592,7 @@ def test_multiple_blocktxn_response(self, test_node):
         # Send the same blocktxn and assert the sender gets disconnected.
         with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed']):
             test_node.send_without_ping(msg)
-        test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
+            test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
comments.body:
Are the changes of this file intentional? Don't we expect these debug logs to be added by the `send_without_ping` call only?

Why not the following diff?
```diff
diff--- a/test/functional/p2p_compactblocks.py
+++ b/test/functional/p2p_compactblocks.py
@@ -590,9 +590,9 @@ class CompactBlocksTest(BitcoinTestFramework):
                test_node.last_message["getdata"].inv[0].type == MSG_BLOCK | MSG_WITNESS_FLAG
 
         # Send the same blocktxn and assert the sender gets disconnected.
-        with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed']):
+        with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed'], timeout=2):
             test_node.send_without_ping(msg)
-            test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
+        test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
 
     def test_getblocktxn_handler(self, test_node):
         node = self.nodes[0]
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,7 +592,7 @@ def test_multiple_blocktxn_response(self, test_node):
         # Send the same blocktxn and assert the sender gets disconnected.
         with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed']):
             test_node.send_without_ping(msg)
-        test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
+            test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
comments.body:
> Why not the following diff?
> 
> ```diff
> diff--- a/test/functional/p2p_compactblocks.py
> +++ b/test/functional/p2p_compactblocks.py
> @@ -590,9 +590,9 @@ class CompactBlocksTest(BitcoinTestFramework):
>                 test_node.last_message["getdata"].inv[0].type == MSG_BLOCK | MSG_WITNESS_FLAG
>  
>          # Send the same blocktxn and assert the sender gets disconnected.
> -        with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed']):
> +        with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed'], timeout=2):
>              test_node.send_without_ping(msg)
> -            test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
> +        test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
>  
>      def test_getblocktxn_handler(self, test_node):
>          node = self.nodes[0]
> ```

Setting a timeout and polling the debug log in a loop just seems brittle, confusing, and racy. I don't see the benefit. The goal of this pull is to get rid of those loops where possible.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,7 +592,7 @@ def test_multiple_blocktxn_response(self, test_node):
         # Send the same blocktxn and assert the sender gets disconnected.
         with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed']):
             test_node.send_without_ping(msg)
-        test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
+            test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
comments.body:
> The goal of this pull is to get rid of those loops where possible.

Calling unrelated RPC (`wait_for_disconnect`) just to get rid of those loops adds some confusion for the reader by making them wonder which RPC / code of the whole `with` block is responsible for adding such logs - doesn't help in making the code self documenting imo.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,7 +592,7 @@ def test_multiple_blocktxn_response(self, test_node):
         # Send the same blocktxn and assert the sender gets disconnected.
         with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed']):
             test_node.send_without_ping(msg)
-        test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
+            test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
comments.body:
> > The goal of this pull is to get rid of those loops where possible.
> 
> Calling unrelated RPC (`wait_for_disconnect`) just to get rid of those loops adds some confusion for the reader by making them wonder which RPC / code of the whole `with` block is responsible for adding such logs - doesn't help in making the code self documenting imo.

The last line of code in the context should generally be responsible. This is also the case here:

The debug log is searched for the reason for disconnection, so I think it is clearer to write:

```py
with node.assert_debug_log(['reason for disconnect']):
  p2p.send_a_msg()
  p2p.wait_for_disconnect()
```

Than:

```py
with node.assert_debug_log(['reason for disconnect'], timeout=2):
  p2p.send_a_msg()
  # wait 2 seconds for a disconnect to happen by looping over the debug log tail
# Once the disconnect happened, check that it happened again:
p2p.wait_for_disconnect()
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,7 +592,7 @@ def test_multiple_blocktxn_response(self, test_node):
         # Send the same blocktxn and assert the sender gets disconnected.
         with node.assert_debug_log(['previous compact block reconstruction attempt failed']):
             test_node.send_without_ping(msg)
-        test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
+            test_node.wait_for_disconnect()
comments.body:
I guess it's fine when I look at it from this^ perspective.

> The last line of code in the context should generally be responsible.

Yes, I agree with this statement. The PR author / reviewer should ensure that unrelated code is not stuffed in such `with` blocks.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -418,8 +418,10 @@ def test_sendmsgtopeer(self):
 
         self.log.info("Test sendmsgtopeer")
         self.log.debug("Send a valid message")
+        msg_bytes_before = self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()[-1]["bytesrecv_per_msg"].get("addr", 0)
         with self.nodes[1].assert_debug_log(expected_msgs=["received: addr"]):
             node.sendmsgtopeer(peer_id=0, msg_type="addr", msg="FFFFFF")
+            self.wait_until(lambda: self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()[-1]["bytesrecv_per_msg"].get("addr", 0) > msg_bytes_before)
comments.body:
Nit: Using `-1` as the index gives the impression that there are multiple entries and the last one is used for some reason that the reader doesn't know about. The `0` index doesn't carry that assumption usually.

```diff
--- a/test/functional/rpc_net.py
+++ b/test/functional/rpc_net.py
@@ -418,10 +418,11 @@ class NetTest(BitcoinTestFramework):
 
         self.log.info("Test sendmsgtopeer")
         self.log.debug("Send a valid message")
-        msg_bytes_before = self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()[-1]["bytesrecv_per_msg"].get("addr", 0)
+        msg_bytes_before = self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()[0]["bytesrecv_per_msg"].get("addr", 0)
         with self.nodes[1].assert_debug_log(expected_msgs=["received: addr"]):
             node.sendmsgtopeer(peer_id=0, msg_type="addr", msg="FFFFFF")
-            self.wait_until(lambda: self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()[-1]["bytesrecv_per_msg"].get("addr", 0) > msg_bytes_before)
+            self.wait_until(lambda: self.nodes[1].getpeerinfo()[0]["bytesrecv_per_msg"].get("addr", 0) > msg_bytes_before)
```

comments.body:
Good point. Though, I was just checking my container that was running this patch in a loop. I think this is still racy, because `getpeerinfo` is updated before the debug log. So my patch will intermittently fail:

```
 test  2026-02-14T09:37:34.797636Z TestFramework (INFO): Test sendmsgtopeer 
 test  2026-02-14T09:37:34.797727Z TestFramework (DEBUG): Send a valid message 
 node1 2026-02-14T09:37:34.797858Z [http] [httpserver.cpp:233] [http_request_cb] [http] Received a POST request for / from 127.0.0.1:33442 
 node1 2026-02-14T09:37:34.797891Z [http_pool_1] [rpc/request.cpp:243] [parse] [rpc] ThreadRPCServer method=getpeerinfo user=__cookie__ 
 node0 2026-02-14T09:37:34.798363Z [http] [httpserver.cpp:233] [http_request_cb] [http] Received a POST request for / from 127.0.0.1:52144 
 node0 2026-02-14T09:37:34.798411Z [http_pool_1] [rpc/request.cpp:243] [parse] [rpc] ThreadRPCServer method=sendmsgtopeer user=__cookie__ 
 node0 2026-02-14T09:37:34.798449Z [http_pool_1] [net.cpp:4074] [PushMessage] [net] sending addr (3 bytes) peer=0 
 node1 2026-02-14T09:37:34.798737Z [http] [httpserver.cpp:233] [http_request_cb] [http] Received a POST request for / from 127.0.0.1:33442 
 node1 2026-02-14T09:37:34.798793Z [http_pool_0] [rpc/request.cpp:243] [parse] [rpc] ThreadRPCServer method=getpeerinfo user=__cookie__ 
 test  2026-02-14T09:37:34.799214Z TestFramework (ERROR): Unexpected exception 
                                   Traceback (most recent call last):
                                     File "/b-c/test/functional/test_framework/test_framework.py", line 142, in main
                                       self.run_test()
                                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
                                     File "/b-c/bld-cmake/test/functional/rpc_net.py", line 93, in run_test
                                       self.test_sendmsgtopeer()
                                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^
                                     File "/b-c/bld-cmake/test/functional/rpc_net.py", line 422, in test_sendmsgtopeer
                                       with self.nodes[1].assert_debug_log(expected_msgs=["received: addr"]):
                                            ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
                                     File "/usr/lib/python3.13/contextlib.py", line 148, in __exit__
                                       next(self.gen)
                                       ~~~~^^^^^^^^^^
                                     File "/b-c/test/functional/test_framework/test_node.py", line 584, in assert_debug_log
                                       self._raise_assertion_error(f'Expected message(s) {remaining_expected!s} '
                                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
                                                                   f'not found in log:\n\n{join_log(log)}\n\n')
                                                                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
                                     File "/b-c/test/functional/test_framework/test_node.py", line 229, in _raise_assertion_error
                                       raise AssertionError(self._node_msg(msg))
                                   AssertionError: [node 1] Expected message(s) ['received: addr'] not found in log:
                                    - 2026-02-14T09:37:34.798737Z [http] [httpserver.cpp:233] [http_request_cb] [http] Received a POST request for / from 127.0.0.1:33442
                                    - 2026-02-14T09:37:34.798793Z [http_pool_0] [rpc/request.cpp:243] [parse] [rpc] ThreadRPCServer method=getpeerinfo user=__cookie__
 node1 2026-02-14T09:37:34.799316Z [msghand] [net_processing.cpp:3555] [ProcessMessage] [net] received: addr (3 bytes) peer=0 
 node1 2026-02-14T09:37:34.799433Z [msghand] [net_processing.cpp:5257] [ProcessMessages] [net] ProcessMessages(addr, 3 bytes): Exception 'DataStream::read(): end of data: iostream error' (NSt8ios_base7failureB5cxx11E) caught 
 test  2026-02-14T09:37:34.803544Z TestFramework (DEBUG): Closing down network thread 
 test  2026-02-14T09:37:34.853858Z TestFramework (INFO): Not stopping nodes as test failed. The dangling processes will be cleaned up later. 
 test  2026-02-14T09:37:34.854000Z TestFramework (WARNING): Not cleaning up dir /tmp/test_runner___20260214_092501/rpc_net_152 
 test  2026-02-14T09:37:34.854061Z TestFramework (ERROR): Test failed. Test logging available at /tmp/test_runner___20260214_092501/rpc_net_152/test_framework.log
```

I think the only reliable way here would be a sync-with-ping, like in all other python p2p connections.
